Find the Github for this project here

Introduction: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the ability to process written language like English or other languages and convert it into a format that computers can understand. SQL (Structured Query Language) is a language used to manage and manipulate data within a database system.

SQL has a limited set of operations, making it syntactically simple and easy to learn. This also makes it easier for large language models to generate accurate SQL queries, unlike programming languages like Java, which offer many ways to accomplish the same task.

Natural Language to SQL (NL2SQL) provides an interface that allows non-technical users to interact with databases, explore data, and gather insights without prior SQL knowledge. While a basic understanding of SQL is not required, it is beneficial, as it helps users phrase queries more accurately and obtain better results from the system.

Users who rarely interact with databases no longer need to manually write complex queries. They can simply communicate with the bot and receive accurate responses. Implementing an NL2SQL system saves time and provides a faster, more efficient way to generate real business insights.

Prerequisites for Building This:

  • A working Python environment
  • HANA Cloud
  • AI Core on BTP
  • A dataset to query (for this example, the Spotify listening history dataset from Kaggle)
  • Streamlit to create a chat-style interface for querying the database

My Dataset

 

These are the descriptions of some of the data contained in my dataset. you can find the dataset here, however compared to a real world database; this database is simple and does not have any of the following complications that make a NL2SQL implementation difficult.

  • In a real world scenario the same data can be formatted in many different ways. Sex can be represented as Male, male or M. Different locations have different ways of representing digits eg: 1,000 vs 1.000.
  • If the LLM Lack the domain specific understanding it could misunderstand the user queries.
  • SQL IS Strict with its syntax like every other programming language. if the generated code does not match its strict syntax rules it will fail.
  • Questions can be ambigous and this is why a standard knowledge of SQL is ideal to make this solution work. a simple question about ‘Who is the most popular artist’ can elicit responses such as total minutes played, or who was skipped the least etc.

To address these challenges, we can implement a prompt engineering approach where questions are classified by complexity. More complex questions are checked for ambiguity, and vector embeddings are used to generate accurate and reliable responses.

When a user asks a question, we collect high-quality question/SQL pairs and store them in HANA. The more the system is used, the better it becomes at generating SQL statements. For new questions, vector embeddings are created and searched against the database of existing solutions to find the most relevant response.

But for now this is a basic implementation of the system.

The first step is to create a database schema. this just shows the initial relationship between the tables, how the data can be stored and the columns.

entry.title: Everyday issues: There is no miracle or magic. SAP HANA database needs memory.
entry.content:
last updated: 2025-08-29

Why was this blog post created?
Countless times we are faced with the fact that the cause of a system performance problem is nothing more than an insufficient amount of "working memory".

Fact: SAP HANA needs memory. In case the available "working memory" is insufficient the system won't work properly. General performance issue occurs.
Rule of thumb: the recommendation from SAP is the "tables data" should not use more than 50 % of the available memory.
One stop shop about SAP HANA memory: Collected information about memory in context of SAP HANA

How to check/detect if SAP HANA is having a memory issue?

1. SAP GUI - Transaction Code - DBACOCKPIT (Load History) - some further examples can be found here

In the case of a healthy system, a system in a calm state (e.g. out of working hours or without load) shows a constant used memory value (max. 50% of the available memory). In this case "used memory" = "tables data". When system used actively next to the "tables data" we see "working memory" also. In this case "used memory" = "tables data" + "working memory". The "working memory" increase and decrease during the system usage. We can check the memory usage easily with "Load History" option, e.g. Last 7 Days or with Custom Selections, so we can have a high level overview about the memory usage in general.

There is no room for "working memory" because "tables data" use the majority of the available memory all the time.

2. 3284834 - SQL Statement Collection: "HANA_Configuration_Minichecks" report for SAP HANA

The most general report will contain further information about the issue. Number of low memory unloads (short-term) = 226380 and Memory reclaim activity (s / day) = 26154. These are outrageously high numbers.

|M0430|Number of low memory unloads (short-term)        |      |226380                                                     |0                   |X| 2127458|
|M0435|Number of shrink unloads (short-term)            |      |0                                                          |<= 1000             | | 2127458|
|M0437|Size of unloaded columns (% / day, long-term)    |      |29.24                                                      |<= 3.00             |X| 2127458|
|M0438|Memory reclaim activity (s / day)                |      |26154                                                      |<= 1200             |X| 1999997|
|M0439|Memory reclaim maximum duration (s)              |      |57                                                         |<= 60               | | 1999997|
|M0440|Topology shared memory utilization (%)           |      |1                                                          |<= 70               | | 1977101|
|M0445|Number of OOM events (short-term)                |      |5                                                          |<= 3                |X| 1999997|
|M0446|Number of OOM events per day (mid-term)          |      |6.71                                                       |<= 3.00             |X| 1999997|
|M0447|Number of alloc. limit OOM events (long-term)    |      |47                                                         |0                   |X| 1999997|​

3. 3330262 - SQL Statement Collection: "HANA_Memory_Overview" report for SAP HANA

The report makes it easy to identify database tables that are using the majority of memory.

What are the consequences?
When the database does not have enough memory to operate, it tries to resolve the situation, it performs "unloads" and "reclaim" activities. These operations are inherent to the functionality of a healthy system, but in the case of a system constantly struggling with memory problems, they result in a constant and never-ending loop. Continuous reclaim and unload activity results in continuous resource (e.g. CPU) usage. The unloading also could affect a database table(s) that should not be removed from memory because it is in general use, meaning it will be reloaded soon again.

What is the conclusion?
There is no miracle or magic. To handle the high memory footprint you have the following options:
1. Data Management of general tables and technical tables. Reference: 3348393 - Overview of the data management process in the context of SAP HANA
2. Increase the available memory in the system.

entry.title: How to Prepare for SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition Certification (with Sample Questions)
entry.content:
In this blog, I’ll share practical tips to help you to prepare and be able to pass the SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition certification (E_S4CPE_2405). While the post is especially helpful for those aiming to get certified, it also provides useful insights for SAP developers, Basis Admin, SAP Architects, Project Managers, and anyone who works daily in SAP ERP projects or operations.

You often start preparing for a certification and end up confused or lost, what are the right resources, and how deep should you go through different materials and references?

As a Microsoft and SAP Certified , I always tell new learners: preparing for a certification is like learning English as a second language—you want to be able to use it effectively in your day-to-day work, not become Shakespeare!
Here, I share the exact resources I use in my day-to-day role as an SAP Architect—drawing on over 20 years of hands-on experience in the SAP space. I’ve also included the key materials that can help you confidently prepare for the SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition.

I’ll be updating this post from time to time, since SAP technology and S/4HANA continue to evolve at a fast pace!

Being a successful SAP Solution consultant or SAP Expert requires a deep understanding of both on-premises and hyperscaler technologies, combined with hands-on experience from real customer projects. On top of that, strong expertise in SAP solutions is essential. Earning the SAP S/4 HANA certification is just the beginning of this journey.

This is the second blog of series, I’m going to share practical insights to help you prepare and succeed to achieve this as a goal.

 Why Get SAP Certified? Real-World Benefits:

  • Being certified earns immediate credibility customers, partners, and hiring managers are more likely to trust your knowledge and decisions.
  • SAP certification improves your chances of landing your desired role.
  • Certified professionals often qualify for higher rates, promotions, and leadership roles in SAP projects.
  • In some cases (e.g., security reviews, migration, SOC 2 documentation), certification adds weight to your approval or sign-off.
  • The annual certification renewal process ensures your knowledge stays current, especially with cloud solutions and SAP's evolving product roadmap.
  • Certification validates your hands-on skills and prepares you to deliver better results in real SAP implementations.
  • Certified professionals are more likely to be chosen for challenging or high-impact projects.
  • Certification gives you recognition within the broader SAP ecosystem.

 Exam Topics and Focus Areas

To pass the certification you’ll need a score of 72% or higher, SAP outlines the following key areas:

  • Introduction to Cloud Computing and SAP Cloud ERP Deployment Options (11% - 20%)
  • Data Migration and Business Process Testing (11% - 20%)
  • Implementing with a Cloud Mindset, Building the Team, and Conducting Fit-to-Standard Workshops (11% - 20%)
  • System Landscapes and Identity Access Management (11% - 20%)
  • Configuration and the SAP Fiori Launchpad (11% - 20%)
  • Extensibility, Integration, and Clean Core (11% - 20%)

 Key Areas of Study

To gain the knowledge required, focus on the following areas:

  • Characteristics of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • RISE with SAP Methodology
  • Customer transition paths to SAP S/4 HANA
  • New Implementation (Greenfield)
  • System Conversion (Brownfield)
  • Selective Data Transition (Bluefield)
  • Key Stockholders and their role & responsibilities
  • System landscapes used to implement SAP S/4HANA
  • S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition release upgrade
  • Cloud ALM Implementation Project setup for S/4 HANA
  • System Preparation Activities for conversion
    • Analyse customer’s exiting business process (Signavio)
    • Run and review SAP Readiness check report
  • Identity Access Management in S/4 HANA
    • Creating users in S/4 HANA
    • Business Role vs System Admin Role
    • Fiori Launchpad UI
  • SAP Fiori Launchpad
    • Applications and users
    • Content Manager
    • App Manager
  • Fit-to-Standard analysis workshops (mostly for greenfield customers)
  • Business processes configuration, evaluation , improvement
  • Working with SAP Fiori Launchpad
    • My Home, Spaces and Pages Layout
    • Embedded help support and Joule
    • Ange Team and Responsibilities app
    • Situation Handling
  • Extensibility tools for S/4 HANA
    • Clean core tiers
    • Key user In-App Extensibility
    •  Developer In-App Extensibility
    • Side by Side Extensibility with BTP
  • Setting up integration in S/4 HANA
    • Integration Solution Advisory Methodology
    • Setting up integrations with various recourses
    • Integration Monitoring with Cloud ALM
  • Data migration methods to S/4 HANA
  • Testing types and strategy
    • Cloud ALM for test case and test plan
    • Cloud ALM test Automation (Tricentis)

 Note: All the resources listed below are free. You may only need to create a Universal ID to track your progress if the resource is from SAP Learning Hub.

Exploring SAP Cloud ERP (Learning Course)

Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

 From Classic ABAP to Clean Corse

S/4 HANA Fully-Activated Appliance on Hyperscalers  (30 days trail)

S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition free (14 days trail)

Before we start the sample questions , let me explain different types of SAP ERP provisioning.

SAP ECC was traditionally deployed in on-premises environments or customer data centres. With the introduction of S/4HANA, cloud provisioning options became available alongside traditional deployments.

Current Types of SAP ERP Deployment Methods

Cloud Editions

  • S/4HANA Cloud, public edition – Multi-tenant SaaS, fully managed by SAP.
  • S/4HANA Cloud, private edition – Single-tenant, SAP-managed infrastructure.

Note:  Although it runs on cloud infrastructure, S/4HANA Cloud, private edition shares more operational and management characteristics with on-premises deployments (greater customer control, customization, directly accessible via customer's network with no Egress cost, and lifecycle management).

On-Premises with Private Editions

  • S/4HANA Private Edition On-Premises managed by SAP (HEC – HANA Enterprise Cloud or ECS – Enterprise Cloud Service) – SAP hosts and operates the system in hyperscalers  on behalf of the customer.
  • S/4HANA Private Edition On-Premises at hyperscalers – Hosted by AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud but managed by the customer or a systems integrator.
  • S/4HANA Private Edition for Government (National security Service -NS2 ) – Specialized U.S.  deployment for government and defense, meeting the highest national security certifications in U.S and Canada .
  • S/4HANA On-Premises in customer data center – Fully customer-managed.
  • S/4HANA On-Premises via SAP certified partners – Deployed using appliances in a customer data center.

Note: RISE with SAP is not a deployment method , it is a bundle offering with one contract.

Legacy Options

  • SAP ECC in customer data center (on-premises) – Classic model, customer-managed.
  • SAP ECC at hyperscalers – Often a transitional step (Unicode migration, system prep) before moving to S/4HANA in cloud environment.

I've put together 15 sample questions to help you prepare for the exam. These questions are a bit more challenging than the ones you'll typically see on the actual test:

Sample Questions

  1. Which choice is the main used of Launchpad Content Manager? There are 2 correct answers to this question
    1. Manage technical catalogs
    2. Create custom business catalogs
    3. Perform mass changes on business catalogs
    4. Add or remove catalogs content references

  2. In an S/4HANA Private Edition implementation, which type of testing focuses on verifying that the overall system still works as expected after applying changes such as upgrades, patches, or configuration updates?
    1. Unit Test
    2. Business Process Test
    3. User Acceptance Test
    4. Regression Test

  3. During an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project using the SAP Integration Solution Advisory Methodology (ISA-M), which activity would you expect to complete before selecting integration technologies or designing detailed interfaces?
    1. Defining target integration domains and aligning them with business priorities
    2. Establishing governance guidelines for integration domains and setting decision-making processes
    3. Executing end-to-end interface tests with all involved applications
    4. Configuring middleware connections between S/4HANA and third-party systems

  4. A customer is moving from SAP ECC to the latest release of SAP S/4HANA, which will be hosted and managed by the ECS team. Their requirement is to migrate both master data and full historical transactional data into the new environment. Which transition approach would best meet their needs?
    1. System conversion
    2. Select data transition
    3. Lift & shift
    4. Greenfield

  5. How are SAP Best Practices initially deploy in S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition system?
    1. Through SAP Transport Management
    2. Through SAP Cloud ALM
    3. Through SAP Activate Methodology
    4. Through SAP Solution Builder

  6. A customer running ECC plans to move to SAP S/4HANA Private Edition through a system conversion. They want to follow SAP’s recommended preparation steps to confirm technical readiness, understand functional impacts, and plan for custom code remediation.
    Which of the following sequences reflects SAP’s best practice?
    1. Run the SAP Readiness Check → Review the Simplification Item List → Perform ATC custom code analysis
    2. Perform ATC custom code analysis → Run the SAP Readiness Check → Review the Simplification Item List
    3. Review the Simplification Item List → Run the SAP Readiness Check → Perform ATC custom code analysis
    4. Run the SAP Readiness Check → Perform ATC custom code analysis → Update the Simplification Item List

  7. You are on an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project where the customer needs to deliver advanced custom business logic that must:
    1.  Reuse internal ABAP application objects (e.g., BAPIs, CDS views) without exposing them via remote APIs first.
    2.   Participate in the same LUW as standard S/4 transactions when required.
    3. Remain upgrade-safe and fully compliant with the “clean core” principle.
    4. Avoid the performance overhead of cross-system remote calls.

           Which approach best meets all of these constraints for a Tier-3 developer extension?

  1. Build the logic in the ABAP environment on SAP BTP (standalone Steampunk) using side-by-side extensions, avoiding any in-stack custom code.
  2. Modify standard ABAP code directly inside S/4HANA to embed the logic within existing processes.
  3. Use SAP Build Apps to deliver the functionality as a low-code/no-code side-by-side extension on SAP BTP.
  4. Develop in the embedded Steampunk ABAP environment inside the S/4HANA system, following in-app extension guidelines and ensuring upgrade safety.

8.  During the Realize phase of an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project using SAP Activate, the team encounters multiple fit-to-standard gaps that require custom extensions. At the same time, performance issues are found during integration testing, and the customer insists on adding new scope items not originally in the signed backlog.

Which of the following actions are fully aligned with the Activate methodology’s Realize phase best practices? (Select TWO)

  1. Perform configuration in the Quality system based on the backlog items confirmed in the Explore phase and manage any new scope through formal change control.
  2. Re-open Fit-to-Standard workshops to capture and approve all new requirements before continuing configuration.
  3. Conduct performance tuning and regression testing as part of iterative configuration cycles before the formal User Acceptance Test.
  4. Postpone addressing integration performance issues until after cutover, since Realize focuses on functional build.
  5. Implement all new customer scope immediately to avoid delays, updating the backlog informally.

9. You are in the preparation phase for an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project and need a platform that provides mission-based guidance, best practices, and ready-to-use service configurations for deploying and extending solutions on SAP BTP. The customer also wants visibility into estimated service costs and technical prerequisites before starting.

        Which SAP platform best meets this need?

  1. SAP Store
  2. SAP Discovery Centre
  3. SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  4. SAP Cloud ALM

10. SAP Cloud ALM You are implementing the latest DMOVE2S4 conversion method (available since SUM 2.0 SP17) for migrating your SAP ECC system from on-premises to hyperscaler cloud. Considering the technical architecture and SUM execution flow, which statements are correct? (Select TWO)

  1. You execute SUM from a newly installed AAS in the target cloud environment, and during the ASCS_ASK phase, SUM automatically detects the remote ASCS instance and offers an "ASCS instance move" dialog to relocate central services to the same target host
  2. You must manually pre-install both AAS and ASCS instances in the target cloud before initiating SUM, ensuring network latency remains below 20ms with minimum 400 MB bandwidth between environments
  3. SUM execution begins from the source PAS while simultaneously creating a shadow AAS instance in the target cloud, with ASCS migration occurring during the EU_CLONE_MNG phase through automated system move protocols
  4. The conversion utilizes standard DMO functionality rather than "DMO with system move," requiring manual post-processing of shared filesystems (/sapmnt/ and /usr/sap/trans) and RFC adjustments after SUM completion

11. In your SAP S/4HANA Private Edition system, you need to manage role maintenance efficiently. Which methods are correct for role management? (Select TWO)

  1. Use transaction PFCG to create roles, assign transactions to menu tree, then generate authorization profiles and perform user master record comparison 
  2. Use transaction SU01 to directly assign authorization profiles to users without generating profiles through role maintenance
  3. Use transaction SU01 to assign users to roles, maintain validity periods, then perform user comparison to activate authorization profiles in user master records
  4. Use Business Role Maintenance Fiori app to create business roles with business catalogs for S/4HANA Private Edition

      12. Which of the following statements correctly describes the Migration Cockpit capabilities and requirements for                     SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations?

  1. Migration Cockpit is a recommended SAP tool that requires separate licensing with dedicated infrastructure setup, exclusively supporting master data migration through manual staging table creation with limited connectivity options
  2. Migration Cockpit is an embedded data migration tool included in S/4HANA licenses that supports both staging tables and direct transfer methods, with value mapping capabilities, simulation features, and comprehensive project management for data migration

entry.title: Lean Services Enablement in Commercial Project Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Commercial Project Management (CPM) provides functions that address the core business process requirements of companies that offer project-based services to their customers. These functions cover multiple processes in an end-to-end scenario spanning the selling, planning, execution, monitoring, and controlling of projects. A core aspect of this process involves the various resource types for carrying out financial activities like Activity, Expense, Human Resource, Material and Revenue.

The SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release introduces Lean Services in CPM which can be used as a resource type for carrying out the financial activities. This extends the earlier introduction of Lean Service Components within Project System (PS) delivered in SAP S/4 HANA 2023 FPS1, providing a seamless experience across both CPM and PS. This blog outlines the essential configuration steps and system prerequisites for activating and integrating Lean Services in CPM, thereby enabling efficient handling of external procurement.

Types of Lean Services

  • Planned Lean Services: Services for which the quantity and exact value is known at the time of creating the purchase requisition.
  • Unplanned Lean Services: Services for which the exact value is not known at the time of creating the purchase requisition. Instead of a fixed price, you enter a value limit that must not be exceeded.

CPM now supports the integration of both Planned and Unplanned Lean Services. This functionality is enabled through the steps described below:

Prerequisite Configuration

  • Define the Resource Types for Lean Service in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Define Resource Types.Figure 1: Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement
  • Assign the resource types to the plan scenario for which financial plan will be done in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types.Figure 2: Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement

Integration with Project System (PS)

The following frameworks in CPM now support Lean Services integration with PS:

Import Planned data to CPM: In order to import data from objects in Project System (PS) into a financial plan, add the import method in IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Methods.

Figure 3: Import Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Import Methods to Import Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Strategies.

Figure 4: Import Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Transfer Planned data to PS: In order to transfer planned data such as quantities, cost, or revenue to business objects in backend systems, add the transfer method in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Methods.

Figure 5: Transfer Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Transfer Methods to Transfer Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Strategies.

Figure 6: Transfer Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Add the import and transfer strategies to the plan scenario in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Version Types.

Figure 7: Link Plan Scenario to Version Types for Lean Services Enablement

Once the above configuration steps are completed, you can seamlessly import the planned data for Lean Service Components from PS, carry out your planning and send the planned data back to PS - just like any other resource type.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #1 in the Series
entry.content:
Organizations around the world are migrating their databases to the cloud, striving to increase operational efficiency, performance, and scalability while reducing costs. But not all databases are created equal.

SAP HANA Cloud is a cloud-native, in-memory database that delivers high performance, scalability, and powerful analytics. It lets you store, process, and query various types of data and models in a single system. Developers can build and deploy intelligent applications, rapidly and at scale. These are just a few of the reasons why so many companies have moved to SAP HANA Cloud.

The value is clear. In a recent study,[1]  IDC found that large enterprises could realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud. This benefit equates to $820,000 per SAP HANA Cloud database per year, with a three-year ROI of 352%. Isn’t that impressive?

The promise of SAP HANA Cloud is attractive for organizations considering a database migration. But you still need to make your business case to justify a modernization initiative.

To help you develop your argument, I’ve created this blog series on the top 10 benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I’ll review some of the key features and capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud and explore how each one can help your organization realize critical business value. Let’s get started.

Multi-model engines

No enterprise relies on only one type of data. Depending on your business, you may be using relational, geospatial, graph, JSON, and vector data, for example. This data can be structured, semi-structured, or unstructured, including text and multimedia content. Some organizations funnel data into single-purpose databases that handle only certain data types. But that database specialization creates additional costs, management effort, and complexity.

SAP HANA Cloud handles diverse workloads within a unified system—processing relational, geospatial, knowledge graph, time series, and vector data for AI applications. This ability to support multi-modal AI, where systems comprehend and process information from various data types, adds versatility. Application developers can integrate diverse data sources into a single application with ease and users can query and blend diverse data types intuitively. Multi-modal AI also reduces the need for complex ETL processes between systems.

The multi-model capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud deliver value by improving productivity. Developers can accelerate the development of AI-infused intelligent applications thanks to native support for predictive modeling, similarity searches, and graph analysis. By reducing the barriers to business data access and enabling faster, more informed decision-making, SAP HANA Cloud can speed up decision-making and improve overall business effectiveness.

Considering these benefits, IDC calculated that SAP HANA Cloud could enable overall productivity gains of 18%, creating an annual business value of $7.8 million. In the study, one entertainment industry executive summarized how the database delivered value for his company.

“SAP HANA Cloud is a more modernized system that has resulted in time savings for developers, analytics, and administration because of the robust integrated tools provided, templates, and modelling capabilities,” he said. “SAP HANA Cloud has enabled my organization to make better business decisions and build better models, which drives business growth.”

Read more to build your business case

Multi-model engines are just one feature of SAP HANA Cloud that can accelerate your organization’s journey to modernization while reducing costs and maximizing efficiency. The following blogs in this series review additional capabilities that can help you build your business case while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Watch out the next blog, which discusses SAP HANA Cloud’s infrastructure independence and next-generation application foundation.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1] . “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Multiple SAP HANA Systems on One Host
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission-critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that must be protected from failures. Business-critical production HANA databases require a well-designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) plan to ensure business continuity and minimize downtimeA primary (active) HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). HSR continuously replicates data to an alternate instance to ensure that changes persist in the event of a primary instance failure.

SAP does support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDS) on a single production SAP HANA hardware installation (or single virtual machine). 

Multiple SAP HANA systems on one host are also known as Multiple Components on One System (MCOS).

SAP support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on a single production SAP HANA host. This is restricted to single-host / scale-up scenarios only.  One Hardware which can be segregated for two HANA tenant installations. Filesystem e can be also be segregated which allows us to do maintenance separately.

Few considerations:

  • RAM:

SAP HANA is memory intensive. Sufficient RAM is crucial for optimal performance, potentially 64GB or 128GB or more depending on the data size and workload.

  • CPU:

Adequate CPU resources are needed to handle the processing demands of multiple HANA instances.

  • Disk Space:

Ensure sufficient disk space for the installation binaries, data volumes, log volumes, and trace files for all instances/tenants.

  • Network:

Plan for network configuration, especially if using a multi-host setup or if the databases need to communicate with other systems.

File System structure:

 

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-1a /hana/data/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-1b /hana/log/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-2a /hana/data/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-2b /hana/log/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

FS structure for 2 DB SID’s SDP – is Prod S4 SDS – is for Quality system

 

 

Production support is restricted to SAP HANA 1.0 SPS 09 (and higher) or SAP HANA 2.0 due to the availability of some resource management parameters (for example affinity). Be aware that running multi-SID on one SAP HANA host may impact performance of various types of operations, as contention for computing resources may occur (memory, cpu, i/o, ...).

SAP strongly recommends performing requisite testing in any project before going live; in general, stress/volume testing is recommended in order to provide good indicators of expected performance. When operating a system that features a multi-SID deployment, SAP recommends to actively make use of the resource management features of SAP HANA (e.g. parameters controlling memory limits, and influencing utilization of CPU cores, etc.) in order to optimize performance.

Business critical Production HANA DB’s require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) for business continuity and allow a SAP technical team to minimize the downtime and increase the application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR).

SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance. In Public Clouds the secondary HANA database instance can either exist within the same region (different Availability Zone) or in a separate region.

 

 

 

SAP systems that are critical to business continuity require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) framework to maximise application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance.

To achieve a near zero Recovery Time Objective (RTO), it is necessary for the primary and secondary HANA database instances to have a similar memory capacity. However, if a higher RTO is acceptable, it is possible to operate the secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint. This can result in considerable cost savings for compute, either by choosing a smaller instance size or leveraging excess memory on the secondary to operate other SAP HANA database workloads.

The reduced memory requirement in the secondary HANA node is achieved by configuring the secondary to not load HANA column data into main memory. A restart is required before promoting it to be primary, at which time it is assumed that the full memory requirement is available. The actual memory demand on secondary host is highly dependent on the HANA System Replication (HSR) configuration and production data change rate. Even by disabling HANA column table loading, the memory demands on the secondary host can go beyond 60% of the actual production HANA memory usage. If the secondary instance is not sized correctly, this can lead to out-of-memory crashes and reduced resilience.

This blog aims at providing a detailed guidance on how to size the secondary HANA database instance while operating with reduced memory footprint with examples for multiple deployment scenarios.

Architecture

There are two common architectures for deploying a secondary HANA database with a lean, or reduced memory footprint in single Hardware.  In this blog we differentiate between them with the terms ‘smaller secondary’ and ‘shared secondary’. Smaller secondary is where the infrastructure is sized smaller than the primary, and then re-sized on takeover. This is sometimes referred to as Pilot Light DR as in the blog Rapidly recover mission-critical systems in a disaster. Shared secondary is where the unused memory is utilized by a non-production or sacrificial instance. SLES documentation refers to this as ‘Cost Optimized Scenario‘.

In both these scenarios, preload of column tables is disabled on the secondary HANA database. The specific configuration to implement this change is to set the HANA database parameter preload_column_tables to false. This configuration needs to be changed to ‘true’ before promoting this instance as primary. Given the manual intervention required and the time taken following a takeover to load the column tables before the HANA database is open for SQL connections, these scenarios are more relevant for a Disaster Recovery (DR) than a High Availability (HA) solution.

Shared secondary

A common use case for a shared secondary scenario is to operate an active quality (QAS) instance along with the secondary HANA database instance on the same host, also called MCOS (Multiple Components One System). This setup requires additional storage to operate the additional instance(s). During a takeover, the instance with lower priority (QAS) can be shutdown to make the underlying host resources available for production workloads.

 

 

For both the scenarios, the secondary HANA database instance configuration is set to preload_column_tables = false. The default value of this parameter is ‘true’ and has to be explicitly changed on the secondary instance to operate with reduced memory. This change is made in HANA database configuration file (global.ini) located in the file path (/hana/shared/<SID>/global/hdb/custom/config).

HANA SR Operation modes

The two operation modes supported by HANA System Replication (HSR) to setup a secondary system are logreplay and delta_datashipping. A high-level comparison between logreplay and delta_datashipping operation modes is presented below.

SAP HANA System Replication Operation Modes

#

Criteria

logreplay

delta_datashipping

1

Operational Behavior

Logs are shipped and continuously applied on the secondary system.

Delta data is shipped from the primary to the secondary occasionally (default 10 min). Logs are only shipped, not applied, until a takeover.

2

Recovery Time

Shorter takeover window, as logs are applied continuously until a failure occurs.

Relatively higher takeover time.

3

Data Transfer Needs

Only logs are shipped, resulting in comparatively lower data transfer needs.

Transfer of both delta data and logs adds to higher data transfers.

4

Network Bandwidth

Due to reduced data transfers, this mode requires relatively lower bandwidth between sites.

This mode requires higher bandwidth between sites.

5

Memory Footprint on DR Instance

Significantly higher memory is required as the column store needs to be loaded for faster delta merge.

The memory footprint is much smaller because the column store isn't loaded into the main memory when column preload is disabled.

6

Multi-tier Replication

Supported

Supported

7

Multi-target Replication

Supported

Not supported

8

Secondary Time Travel

Supported

Not supported

 

 

It is worth noting that in a 3-Tier replication setup, a mix of operation modes is not supported. For example if the primary and secondary HANA database instances are configured to use logreplay for HSR, then delta_datashipping operation mode cannot be used between the secondary and tertiary systems and vice-versa.

SAP Guidance on disabling column preload

The actual memory usage on the secondary host is dependent on the HANA replication operation mode configuration and the preload setting for column tables. Hence it is important to understand the sizing requirements for different operation modes in a HANA System Replication setup. The below chart is an excerpt from SAP Note : 1999880 – FAQ: SAP HANA System Replication (SAP Support Portal login required)

 

As per the above guidance, even with preload = off, the minimum memory requirements for operation mode ‘logreplay’ also factors in the column store memory size of tables with modifications . As a rule of thumb, consider the size of column store tables with data modified in the previous 30 days from current date of evaluation.

SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA provides a collection of SQL scripts that can be used for analysing various administration and performance aspects of SAP HANA database. With minor changes to one of the scripts from this collection, titled ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’, it is possible to provide a rough estimate for the minimum memory required to accommodate these tables. For exact steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section at the end of this blog.

In the following sections, the examples provide details on how to evaluate sizing when deployed in a Shared secondary scenario. Although not shown, a similar sizing exercise is applicable to the Smaller secondary scenario, without the additional considerations of running a second HANA database instance (for example QAS) on the same host.

Option 1 – HSR with Operation Mode: logreplay

In the following example, the primary and secondary production HANA database instances are deployed on two 9TiB High Memory instances. The secondary instance host also hosts a Quality Assurance (QAS) HANA Database Instance. To be able to deploy these instances, the global_allocation_limit for all the three HANA database instances (PRD-Primary, PRD-Secondary, QAS) needs to be evaluated. Following section illustrates how to derive these values.

 

 

 

In the subsequent sections, Global Allocation Limit is referred as ‘GAL’.

  • GAL for Primary instance

On the Primary instance, global_allocation_limit is not set in this example (default value=0 and unit is MB). A default value does not limit the amount of physical memory that can be used by the database. However, as per the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), maximum allocation to HANA database by operating system follows the rule of 90% of the first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

  • GAL for Secondary instance

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and logreplay operation mode is, ‘Row store size + Column store memory size of tables with modifications + 50 GB’. As an example, on the primary instance, the SQL script ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’ was executed and the column tables with modifications for the previous 30 days is identified as 3077 GB. For detailed steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section of this blog.

 

 

Similarly, using SQL script ‘HANA_Memory_Overview’ from SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA, the memory requirements for ‘Row store’ can be determined. An example value of 153 GB is considered for the following evaluation.

Memory required (min) = Row store size

                        + Column store memory size of tables with modifications

                        + 50 GB

Ex: (153 + 3077 + 50) GB = 3280 GB

GAL for DR = 3280 GB^

  ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Note: This value provides the minimum sizing guidance only. It is recommended to allocate additional headroom of 10-20% of this value to accommodate any immediate spike in column store table modifications.

Similarly, global_allocation_limit (GAL) has to be set for the second HANA database instance (QAS) running on the DR site. According to  the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), the sum total of all HANA database allocation limits on a particular host should not exceed 90% of first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)] ≤ {(0.9 * 64) + [0.97 * (Phys Mem GB - 64)]}

Applying this guidance to our example of 9 TiB(9896 GB)  bare metal instance is as follows.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤  {[0.9 * 64] + [0.97 * (9896 - 64)]} GB

                          ≤  9595 GB

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). As the HANA DR instance memory sizing is derived at 3280 GB, the remaining size can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 3280 GB  + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 6314 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Option 2 – HSR with Operation Mode: delta_datashipping

This section provides an overview of HANA System Replication deployed with ‘delta_datashipping’ operation mode and the procedure to evaluate the memory sizing for each individual instance.

 

 

 

  • GAL for Secondary instance

 

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and delta_datashipping operation mode is as follows. Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (Row store size + 20 GB)]

Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (153 + 20 GB)]

GAL for DR: The minimum required value for GAL_DR = 173 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). In the previous step, secondary HANA database instance memory sizing is derived at 173 GB, the remaining size on the host can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]   ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 173 GB   + (GAL_QAS)] ≤  9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 9422 GB^

   ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Conclusion

This blog highlights that the cost savings of deploying a secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint may not be realized with logreplay operation mode. This is because of the higher memory demands of column store being loaded into the main memory of secondary HANA database and occurs irrespective of the column table preload setting. This behavior is by design for continuous log replay. In addition, there is a requirement to constantly monitor column store data growth on the primary and adapt memory allocations on the secondary to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) issues on secondary. The operation mode delta_datashipping facilitates better cost savings in comparison to logreplay while disabling the preload of column tables on secondary HANA database instance. However, this choice comes with limitations which may include a higher recovery time and an increased demand for network bandwidth between the replication sites.

Opting for delta_datashipping is usually a trade-off between cost considerations and other limitations of this operation mode as explained in this blog. With relaxed RTO requirements and higher network bandwidth between the replication sites, the use of ‘delta_datashipping’ can be promoted. Also, with larger database instances, the potential for cost savings is higher. This is because the memory footprint on the secondary has a minimum requirement of row store memory and buffer requirements even for smaller database instances. The association between various factors that influence the choice of a particular operation mode and the potential for cost benefits with delta_datashipping option are represented in the following diagram. These factors are independent of each other and can individually influence the ability to use ‘delta_datashipping’ and thereby the cost benefits.

It is also important to understand that the memory requirement calculation for the secondary and subsequent setting of global_allocation_limit, is an iterative process. As the production database size grows, eventually the column store demand for delta merge also grows on the secondary instance. Hence, the memory allocations of secondary and optionally, other HANA database instances provisioned on the same hardware should be monitored periodically and also after mass data loads, go-lives and SAP system specific life-cycle events.

  Identify the parameter 'TOUCH_TYPE' and enter the value as 'MODIFY'

Ex: 'MODIFY' TOUCH_TYPE,       /* ACCESS, SELECT, MODIFY */

BEGIN_TIME

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'BEGIN_TIME' and key in the value as 'C-D30'

Ex: 'C-D30' BEGIN_TIME,

entry.title: Using the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Status App
entry.content:
SAP Note 1257308 - FAQ: Using EarlyWatch Alert provides preliminary information about the Status App. The app tracks the status of the SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) from the arrival of service data through all processing steps at SAP. This app is intended for administrators to troubleshoot the EWA process. This blog will provide a more detailed description of the Status App functionality.

EWA session data can be sent to SAP through various methods. The EWA session data can be sent directly to SAP through the HTTP destination SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL (via SAP-SUPPORT_PARCELBOX) from either an ABAP managed system or an SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, any EWA session data for systems managed by the ECS team are sent via their SAP Focused Run systems on SAP side to be processed. The following Notes and KBAs are provided for more information on all three scenarios.

  • 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP
  • 1684537 - EarlyWatch Alert Not Sent to SAP: Troubleshooting Guide - SAP Solution Manager
  • 2930644 - SAP Focused Run: EarlyWatch Alert Troubleshooting Guide - Guided Answer

After sending EWA session data through one of the available methods it can be unclear whether the EWA data was successfully received by SAP or if there was any issue with the EWA session processing. The EWA Status App allows you to follow the status of your EWA report once it’s sent to SAP.

All EWA session data sent to SAP will be available for review in the EWA Status App, here you will find various details about the EWA sessions you have sent.

You can see the date the EWA session data session was sent, if they have been successfully received by SAP, as well as whether the EWA session could be processed successful or has been generated and posted in the EWA workspace.

Since the EWA session data packages sent to SAP are processed in randomly assigned batches for all customers it can take from a few hours to a few days for your EWA result to be available in various SAP applications like the EWA Workspace, Solution Finder, EWA Dashboard, or as a Word document available for download. Using the Status App allows you to track this process without opening a case.

The general fields available in the EWA Status App that are applicable for all system types are the following columns.

  • System
  • Product
  • Sending System Product
  • Data Received at SAP
  • Collected At

The “System” and “Product” columns will list the long and short SID as well as the product version respectively of the EWA target system.

The “Sending System Product” column, however, will display the product version of the system that transferred the session data to SAP. This is most often a Solution Manager or Focused Run system.  

Finally, the “Data Received at SAP” and “Collected at” columns document the date and time the EWA session package was received by SAP as well as when it was collected on the managed system.

Data Transfer Status Details

In the EWA Status App the “Data Transfer Status Details” column can have one of three status’. The status’ are Rejected, Ignored, Success. As you would expect Success simply indicates the EWA session data was successfully transferred to SAP. The other two status’ can be indicative of various errors. I will describe the most common in more detail below.

"Ignored (duplicate)"

This status indicates that the EWA is sent multiple times per week for the same system. You should check to see if the EWA is being sent from both Solution Manager and the managed system. The same checks should be performed for on prem FRUN systems. The EWA could also be sent multiple times per week from the same system. All will result in the same status.

"Ignored (not in allow list)"

This status can be caused by a few errors. However, the most common would be that either the license or maintenance certificate for the system is expired.

Recommendation:

Review the SLICENSE transaction in Solution Manager if used as well as the managed system to ensure both are up to date.

"Rejected (system time in future)"

The system runs with a system time deviating from official time. 

Recommendation:

The System Time can be synced manually by your system Admin. However, it is likely that this is a temporary change for testing purposes and it will sync automatically via Internet. If not working, your Admin can start this sync process at the OS Level.

 

"Rejected (no data)"

The service data that arrived at SAP is either not readable or empty or incomplete and thus important parts are completely missing.

Recommendation:

This would indicate that there are issues with EWA session data collection or service data quality. We recommend reviewing the resolution steps in the KBA 1824881 - Summary of Grey Rated EWA Reports - SAP Solution Manager.

"Rejected (non-productive)"

Only for productive and test systems the EWA is processed at SAP. Based on the system role the service data can be rejected. This is true for managed systems before ST-PI 740 SP23 (ST-PI 2008_1_7xx SP33) more information on the adjusted criteria can be found in SAP Note 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP.

"Rejected (not authorized)"

The technical communication user used for upload is not authorized to upload for this system.

Or

The technical communication user used for upload is not valid anymore.

Or

The user used for upload is not a technical communication user.

Recommendation:

You will need to ensure the S user assigned to both the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL and SAP-SUPPORT_PACELBOX HTTP destinations is a valid technical user. The following KBA outlines the requirements for the assigned user.

2174416 - Creation and activation of Technical Communication Users - SAP for Me

"Rejected (other reason)"

Create a case with component SV-SCS-EWA-GEN.

"Rejected (content size exceeds limit)"

The service data exceeds the size limit.

"Rejected (unknown system type)"

Supported technical system types are ABAP, HANA, JAVA and BOBJ. When extracting the leading system from the service data either no technical system type was determined, or the technical system type is not supported by EarlyWatch Alert.

Recommendation:

If using Solution Manager it is recommended that you review the system information maintained in LMDB. Ensure the technical system type is maintained and that it is a supported type.

In addition, in some scenarios is may be required to replace the SDCCN service definitions. The following KBA outlines the process and under which circumstances these steps should be performed.

SAP KBA 1765141 - When should the Service Definitions be completely replaced (Delete and Download) using the steps outlined in SAP Note 727998?

"Rejected (data too old)"

The service data that was sent to SAP was collected more than 112 days ago. Such old service data is not processed by SAP.

 

Details on Report Status, Dashboard Status, and Solution Finder Status

These three columns are relatively binary. The Status can either be “Success” or “Missing” / blank. In rare instances you can receive the status “Error (Initialization Failed)”. In this instance a case should be opened in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

The Report Status will be successful when the EWA document has been successfully generated. Until this point this column will remain blank. As mentioned previously it can take from a few hours to several days for your EWA result to be available. If the EWA session data was successfully received by SAP there is no cause for concern if the EWA report is not immediately available.

The same is true of the columns “Dashboard Status” and “Solution Finder Status”. When these applications are fully populated the EWA column status here in the Status App will change to Success. Prior to this the status will remain either blank or have the status “Missing”. Neither status is a cause for concern. If after several days the status of these columns remains unpopulated you should open a case in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

 

2 Billion Record Limit Status and Number Range Forecast Details

This column is system dependent. These checks are in reference to the maximum table size for HANA systems. The maximum table size cannot exceed 2 billion records for a HANA system without detrimental impact to the system.

However, the status “Missing” is most often applied to systems that do not have a HANA component. This information is not relevant to your system if you do not have a HANA Component and is not a cause for concern. You should review the EWA for the affected system to confirm that there is no associated HANA DB.

For HANA systems where this check was not successfully performed the status will instead be “No Forecast”, “Partial Success”, or “Unconfident Forecast”.

These may be a cause for concern and your first steps should be to review the RTCCTOOL recommendations of both the managed system and Solution Manager. You are looking for any red warning objects related to HANA session data, ST-PI, or ST-A/PI.

More information about the exact limitations of HANA are documented in the KBA 2154870 - How-To: Understanding and defining SAP HANA Limitations.

Additionally, more information can be found in the HANA Sizing Blog.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #2 in the Series
entry.content:
In my previous blog, I discussed how SAP HANA Cloud delivers critical business benefits to organizations that migrate their database to the cloud. Advanced features such as multi-model engines allow enterprises to increase productivity and reduce complexity. In a recent study,[1]  IDC calculated that large enterprises can realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud.

Understanding how the specific capabilities of the database benefit your organization is key to helping you justify a cloud modernization initiative. Let’s look at two more capabilities that can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud: infrastructure independence and a next-generation application foundation.

Infrastructure independence

Your database requirements constantly evolve. To keep up with changing business conditions, customer requirements, and user demand, you need an infrastructure that matches your needs. A solution that offers vendor independence is key.

SAP HANA Cloud offers multi-cloud flexibility so you can run on your hyperscaler of choice. The cloud-native architecture runs on Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform, Microsoft Azure, Alibaba Cloud, and soon, SAP data centers. You can choose a hyperscaler without fear of vendor lock-in.

 

Because it uses cloud-native technologies, the architecture offers consistent, high performance no matter which provider you choose. Automated failover and recovery features enhance resilience. Database administrators can provision new instances in just minutes. And elastic scaling capabilities respond to changing workload demands in real time.

SAP HANA Cloud also reduces the complexity of database operations. It simplifies integration across hybrid or multi-cloud environments and provides direct access to data in SAP applications. Because SAP HANA Cloud is a fully managed database-as-a-service (DBaaS) from SAP, your IT personnel are free to focus on value-added tasks. What’s more, SAP HANA Cloud covers your database, infrastructure, and management requirements, eliminating the need for a separate infrastructure contract with your hyperscaler.

The IDC study assessed the financial impact of infrastructure independence and the associated flexibility. After deploying SAP HANA Cloud, study participants reported a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams and said that database deployments were executed 38% faster. Considering the costs of IT staff management, unplanned downtime, and database infrastructure, IDC calculated a 35% lower annual total cost of ownership for SAP HANA Cloud over a three-year period.

According to one study participant with a large database environment,

“SAP HANA Cloud has enabled us to redirect IT staff to focus more on the production environment, new development, integration, and leveraging AI. Overall, this allows them to help drive revenue and increase productivity.”

Next-generation application foundation

To gain business value from modern, intelligent applications, you need a sophisticated database that can support multiple data types from various sources, process data in real time, and deliver insightful analytics.

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, an open cloud platform with data management, analytics, AI, IoT, blockchain technologies and application development services. Together, SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP form a full-stack solution that includes powerful integration features and an intuitive interface, all under one commercial model.  In addition, SAP HANA Cloud is the trusted database that powers SAP’s mission-critical solutions, such as SAP Business Cloud, with multi-model engines and enterprise-grade performance and reliability.

SAP HANA Cloud also empowers developers to create intelligent applications using today’s most advanced technologies. With this database, teams can build applications that use generative AI, machine learning, and specialized engines to handle vectors, knowledge graphs, property graphs, and spatial processing. It also manages semi-structured JSON data with ACID compliance. The resulting applications are context-aware and offer secure connections to critical business data and curated data products from SAP.

This integrated approach allows applications to ingest and process data in multiple formats and from various sources, including SAP and third-party solutions. Users get live access to critical business information without data replication. Native connectivity to various data sources unifies disparate data streams, offering a single holistic view of your enterprise data. Applications can respond to events in real time, support automated processes, and enable ad-hoc decision-making using current and historical data.

 Having a next-generation application foundation adds IT, performance, and business enablement benefits, according to the IDC study. After adopting SAP HANA Cloud, participating organizations realized a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams. Query speed and response time increased by 31% and 29%, respectively. Enterprises processed 151% more data sources and 77% greater data volume (in terabytes) than in previous environments. Business operations improved, thanks to enhanced analytics that led to better business decisions, an accelerated application development process, and more agile deployment of database resources. Participants also realized end-user productivity gains of 18%, leading to annual gross revenue gains of nearly $40 million per organization.

A study participant who works in the healthcare industry summarized the value of SAP HANA Cloud.

“SAP HANA Cloud provides my organization the ability to apply parallel processes and maintain scalable databases,” he said. “As a result, we have been able to build a lot of applications with machine learning and AI capabilities. With SAP HANA Cloud, it is easier to integrate these applications.”

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the next blog to learn how multi-dimensional elastic scalability and intelligent data tiering features in SAP HANA Cloud can help you build your business case while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.
